24.title: "Dad, Can I Change My Answer?"
24.author: by Mort Walker and Dik Browne

25.heading: Power Failures.
25.title: "The Machine to Make Diamonds"
25.author: Paul Parker
notes: Summary: A murderous inventor's haste to try his new machine causes a power failure that saves the man he framed from execution in the electric chair.

26.heading: Power Failures.
26.title: "Take This Candle and Stop That Bickering"

32.heading: Power Games.
32.title: Neck and Neck
32.author: by Sun-Hee Lee ; translation, Sunah Kim Schultz ; retouch and lettering, Abelardo Bigting ; production artist, Yoohae Yang.
notes: Translation of: Maksang Makha.

Summary (from SkyRiver): The daughter of Seoul's most powerful crime boss, Dabin Choi, likes Eugene, the son of one of her father's associates. Unfortunately, Eugene thinks of Dabin like a little sister. And, one of Dabin's new classmates is the son of her father's rival. Everyone starts playing power games, just like their fathers.

57.title: "Power Girl"
57.author: Paul Levitz, writer ; Joe Staton and Joe Orlando, artists

58.title: Power Girl : Bomb Squad
58.author: Judd Winick, writer ; Sami Basri, artist ; Sunny Gho, Jessica Kholinne, colorists ; John J
notes: 1 v. : col. ill. ; 26 cm.
"Originally published in single magazine form in Power Girl 13-18."
Summary (from SkyRiver): Power Girl is unable to recall anything from the time she was under the control of Max Lord and her business begins to suffer from the distractions of being a heroine.

59.heading: Power Girl.
59.title: JSA vs. Kobra
59.author: Eric S
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): The members of the Justice Society are forced to change their tactics when a suicide bomber targets headquarters and Kobra gets a new leader, Jason Burr, who has the skills to outmaneuver Power Girl, the Flash, and the rest of the Society as they chase him around the world.
"Originally published in single magazine form in JSA vs. Kobra 1-6."

60.heading: Power Girl.
60.title: The Lost Daughters of Earth 2
60.author: Paul Levitz, writer, George Pérez, artist.
notes: 1 v. : col. ill. ; 26 cm.
(World's Finest ; v. 1)
"Originally published in single magazine form in Worlds' Finest 0-5."

Summary (from SkyRiver): Flung from the parallel world of Earth 2 to our own Earth during a violent battle, Robin and Supergirl find themselves trapped in this strange land. Over time they have adopted the new identities of Huntress and Power Girl and protect this world like it's their own, but it will never be their home. Will the World's Finest ever find their way back to Earth 2?

v. 3. The Superman, Wonder Woman, Nightwing: Night Force, The Joker's wild, Trials of the Flash, Tales of the Green Lantern, Powergirl, JLA.

notes: "Tangent based on concepts by Dan Jurgens."
Complete in 3 vols.
Summary (from SkyRiver): Some of DC comics most beloved characters are reinvented.

notes: 1 v. : col. ill. ; 26 cm.

"All over the globe a mysterious girl has been making news, averting disasters and rescuing hundreds. As Atlee's stunts grab the attention of the world, the mover-and-shaker also draws the attention of Supergirl and Power Girl."

77.title: Power Girl
77.author: script, Justin Gray, Jimmy Palmiotti ; art, Amanda Conner ; colors, Paul Mounts ; letters, John J
77.appears_in: Hill. 22 p. in Power Girl, no. 1 (July 2009).
notes: Summary: As Power Girl (Karen Starr) tries to re-start her life and her company, Manhattan is attacked by robotic machines dropping from a vortex in the sky. In the vortex, she comes face-to-face with the Ultra-Humanite (Gerard Shugel) who has taken Manhattan hostage in order to force Power Girl to let him transfer his brain into her body.
Data from Jim Van Dore, Lou Mazzella, Valmiki Annamanthadoo, et al. via Grand Comics Database.

78.title: Power Girl
78.author: script, Jimmy Palmiotti, Justin Gray ; art, Amanda Conner ; colors, Paul Mounts ; letters, John J
78.appears_in: Hill. 22 p. in Power Girl, no. 2 (Aug. 2009).
notes: Summary: While the Ultra-Humanite prepares to transfer his brain into Power Girl he tells her how he was born with a degenerative disease, but because of his genius he was able, with the aid of a woman named Santanna, to keep himself alive until he could transfer his brain into the body of an albino ape.
Data from Jim Van Dore, Lou Mazzella, Jerry Hillegas, et al. via Grand Comics Database.

79.title: Power Girl
79.author: script, Jimmy Palmiotti, Justin Gray ; art, Amanda Conner ; colors, Paul Mounts ; letters, John J
79.appears_in: Hill. 22 p. in Power Girl, no. 3 (Sept. 2009).
notes: Summary: Using her freeze breath, Power Girl escapes Ultra-Humanite's restraints and incapacitates the villain. Then, with Terra bringing the Earth up to meet Manhattan, Power Girl severs the cables holding it to Ultra-Humanite's ship and gently lowers the ship itself.
Data from Jim Van Dore, Lou Mazzella, Valmiki Annamanthadoo, et al. via Grand Comics Database.

"Prelude to Blackest Night."
"Originally published in single magazine form in Green Lantern 38-42, Blackest night 0."

Summary (from SkyRiver): Hal Jordon, Earth's Green Lantern, happens into the Vega System, an off-limits sector, during the War of Light and finds himself face-to-face with Agent Orange, whose light renders its bearer selfish, insatiably greedy, and power-hungry.

102.heading: Power-Hungry Conglomerates.
102.title: Darkside Blues
102.author: story, Hideyuki Kikuchi ; art, Yuho Ashibe ; translator, Tomoe Spencer.
notes: 1 v. : ill. ; 19 cm.

"In the near future, almost the entire world lies in the iron grip of the power-hungry conglomerate, Persona Century Corporation. The city of Shinjuku has, until this point, remained outside the grasp of this greedy company, but in spite of this, or perhaps because of it, it has become a dangerous and lawless town, teeming with rebels and terrorists. One day, a handsome, enigmatic young man by the name of Darkside mysteriously appears in Shinjuku. He, along with a small band of rebels, will attempt to break Persona's stranglehold on the world, if it isn't too late."

Data from John Greb, Gregg Whitmore and Peter Croome via Grand Comics Database.

137.title: Power Loss ; pt. 2 "Mortal Wounds"
137.author: script, Kurt Busiek ; pencils, Tom Grummett ; inks, Prentis Rollins ; colors, Alex Sinclair ; letters, Comicraft
137.appears_in: 22 p. in The Power Company, no. 9 (Dec. 2002).
notes: Summary: The team gathers around the comatose Josiah Power and reviews how the activities of the prior day played out. Manhunter looks at how he, Striker Z and Green Arrow bested Biomax. Skyrocket goes over how she, Bork and Sapphire were bested by The Cadre and Doctor Polaris. This leads to a junior partners meeting which Josiah cools down. The hospital scene ends with the team pledging to find the person who shot Josiah, only to have Lt. Driver deflate the moment by telling them that the shooter has already been caught by the police.
Data from John Greb, Gregg Whitmore and Peter Croome via Grand Comics Database.
